all_paragraphs: Pandas is typically the default choice for data scientists, analysts and engineers when it comes to manipulating and analysing data with Python. The fundamental data structure used when working with this library is the DataFrame. The Pandas DataFrame is a two-dimensional structure consisting of rows and columns of data, not unlike an Excel spreadsheet or SQL database table.

Once data is made available in this data structure you can perform a variety of operations to prepare your data for analysis. In the following article, I am going to introduce you to some of the basic concepts for working with Pandas DataFrames.
The pandas.DataFrame() function can be used to convert data, in the form of series, arrays, constants or lists, into a DataFrame.
The code below takes a list integers and converts them to a pandas DataFrame. We pass in a list of columns names and use the pandas.head() function to display the first few rows of data.

For the remainder of this tutorial, we will be working with an open-source data set taken from the UCI machine learning repository. This data set consists of a number of features of an adult such as age, education level and marital status together with a target which denotes whether or not they earn an income above $50k pa.
We can download this dataset directly from the URL using the pandas.reas_csv() function. This function returns the data as a Pandas DataFrame.
Pandas supports a wide variety of additional methods for importing data, these include:
It is quite common to need to add new columns to a DataFrame to facilitate further analysis of the data. There are a number of ways you may want to do this.

For example, you might want to add a new column based on a condition. In the code below we are using the numpy.where() function to create a column called ‘part-time-hours’ where the value is 1 if ‘hours-per-week’ is less than 35. I have also called pandas.value_counts() to get a quick view of the count of adults in each value in this new column.

In the dataset we are using there is a column containing the age of each person. A common method for better analysing this data type is to group the ages into groups or bins. We can create a new column that does this using the pandas.cut() function. I have used the pandas plotting functionality combined with value_counts() to create a simple visual representation of the distribution.
During data analysis, a commonly performed task is to select subsets of rows and columns from a data set. Pandas provides a number of methods for performing this type of operation.

As we showed above we can select subsets of data based on conditions. Let’s say we wanted to select all rows and columns where the age of the person was over 65. We can do this using the following code.

Pandas DataFrames are indexed and it is also therefore possible to select data based on indexing. You can select data using indexing either via labels in which case you would use the DataFrame.loc() function or via integer-based positions using DataFrame.iloc().
The following code selects all rows for the column labelled ‘occupation’.
This code snippet performs the exact same operation using the integer position of the column.
Real-world data often contains missing or erroneous value which need to be cleaned. Pandas has methods for cleaning missing data from all data types including integers, floats and objects.

To fill missing values with an appropriate value we can use DataFrame.fillna(). Within the fill argument, we can specify a single value such as 0 or a dictionary specifying a different value to fill for each row and/or column.
Alternatively, we can choose to drop rows containing missing values using DatFrame.dropna().
Once you have completed your DataFrame you can export it back to a file or database. Pandas supports a variety of methods for exporting data including:

The Pandas library contains a huge range of useful data analysis functions and tools. The DataFrame not only provides a clear and ordered method for organising your data but also gives you access to these rich data analysis tools. This tutorial provides a simple introduction to the basic DataFrame functionality but there is a lot more scope to using the data once it is organised in this structure. If you want to explore some of the functionality I have outlined in this article in more depth I invite you to check out some of my previous Pandas tutorials.
